results.title: Prejudice: equality ...at what price
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Pamela Williams and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A provocative docu-drama portraying two cases of female discrimination experienced by separate women from unrelated backgrounds. Jessica, a newspaper photographer is subjected to a campaign of sexual harassment and Letitia is denied a promotion and subjected to humiliating racist comments from her colleagues. The stories are linked by the Anti-Discrimination Board, established to investigate and conciliate complaints of prejudice and discrimination. Combines the use of actors and “actual” professional people including Officers of the ADB, union representatives and members of the legal profession play themselves.

results.title: Prehistoric times. - Rev. ed.
results.brief_description: Describes the prehistoric era before life existed on earth and how tiny cell-like plants and animals started to evolve in the seas.

results.title: Prehistoric times the world before man
results.brief_description: Diagrams, actual fossil remains and models are used to recrate the earth in its presumed form during the two-billion year period prior to the coming of man. Explains the most important geological and biological developments of the five great geological eras - Archeozoic, Proterozoic, Paleozoic, Mesozoic and Cenozoic.

results.title: Prehistoric Pet Shop
results.creator_credit: Chris Barnard, Mathew Buck, George Ing, Create Studios, Dacoit Studios, Evil Twin Artworks and First Light
results.brief_description: Prehistoric Pet Shop is about a caveman whose alarm clock stops working. But not just any alarm clock - the clock was a bird with an unfortunate heart problem. The caveman goes to the pet shop to complain about his faulty alarm clock. A homage to Monty Python’s parrot sketch, this hilarious short reveals that complaining can get you more than just a new alarm clock.

results.title: Prehistoric mammals
results.brief_description: Millions of years ago some new animals appeared on earth which had hair and feed their own milk to their young. Many mammals still living today appear to be related to these extinct mammals. This film explores these relationships, which lead to the question of survival.

results.title: Pregnancy and birth
results.creator_credit: Antonio Colacino, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Developing child”.
Derek Llewellyn-Jones, Professor of Obstetrics, University of Sydney, stresses the importance of prenatal care, child birth education and psychoprophylaxis in promoting relaxation and confidence during the birth process. An actual birth is shown.

results.title: Pregnancy after 35
results.creator_credit: Gwen Brown, Alvin Fiering and Polymorph Films
results.brief_description: Uses interviews with middle aged mothers and information from Carole S. McCauley’s book, to allay the fears of women contemplating pregnancy after 35. Shows emotional and physical reactions to pregnancy at this age, discusses Down’s syndrome and demonstrates an amniocentesis which test foetal chromosomes.

results.title: Preface to a life
results.creator_credit: William S Resnick, Samuel A Datlowe and Sun Dial Films
results.brief_description: Shows parental influence on a child’s personality. This is illustrated in a series of episodes which show the effects of an overly solicitous mother and a father who demands too much. For contrast, the film shows the healthy childhood which results when both parents accept their child as an individual with unique characteristics and potentials.

results.title: Preemies : the price tag (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Shows how premature babies in the intensive care unit of a large hospital are kept alive. Most have underdeveloped lungs and have resulting breathing and feeding problems. This raises the issue of the tremendous costs involved and the fact that many babies develop handicaps as a direct result of the intensive care they are given. These can include deafness, blindness, cerebral palsy and mental retardation. Both parents and doctors express opinions on these issues.
